text: that journey here started five years ago
Dave Hughes a Hong Kong born Brits moved
to Rwanda after reading a gripping
account of the 1994 genocide
he built a school and formed a bond with
some young rugby players I saw some guys
playing rugby on the side of the road
went up to them ultimately were doing
got involved started coaching and a
local team they started coaching the
national team and then being a Hong Kong
boy always wanted to bring them out here
to Hong Kong the players went back to
Rwanda and started a rugby revolution
they're bringing the skills they learned
in Hong Kong to players of all ages
despite having very little equipment and
to this day they play on an old soccer
pitch rugby is the fastest growing sport
in the country
Benjamin Macomb Bay was one of the first
Rwandan to play in Hong Kong now he's
part of an elite East African team made
up of Rwandan
Kenyans and League and ins they competed
in the international tennis tournament a
lead-up to the famed rugby sevens when
you're here with me likee it's a dream
because it's a new things come in our
life and we are happy to be here
following in those footsteps
the Rwandan national team played in
their own tournaments these young men
only dreamed of coming to Hong Kong
there are also men who have lived
through a nightmare
according to most estimates a million
people killed in the span of 100 days 27
year-old John Leonard lost family in the
genocide during the war many people were
killed because they were Hutus or
tootsies
but now we are glad this peace we all
talk the same language we are all
together the Hong Kong skyline and it's
pictures are about as big of a culture
shock as you can get for these players
and playing in this tournament is the
culmination of years of hard work but
for them rugby is so much more than just
a sport they say it's been a tool that's
helped them come together and heal as a
nation
in Ronda we call ourselves Randy's like
that's one tribe the whole family
Randy's if anyone wants to ask any one
of us you know just tell me I'm Randy's
these rugby players have high hopes for
their country's future and will continue
that tradition of inspiring others back
home
Laura Westbrook BBC news Hong Kong
